An administrator is migrating 100 virtual machines from one ESXi Host to another. The current 1GigE network cards are only migrating four virtual machines simultaneously.
Which action should the administrator take to increase that number to eight?

discussion.content:

Network Limits for Migration with vMotion
vMotion 5.0, 5.1, 5.5, 6.0, 6.5, 6.7, 7.0 1GigE 4VM
vMotion 5.0, 5.1, 5.5, 6.0, 6.5, 6.7, 7.0 10GigE 8VM

Selected Answer: C
Port mirroring is not a solution for increasing the number of virtual machines migrated simultaneously from one ESXi host to another. Port mirroring is a networking feature that allows traffic on one port (or ports) of a network switch to be forwarded to another port for analysis or monitoring purposes.
A 10GigE network card provides significantly higher bandwidth compared to a 1GigE network card. With more bandwidth available, the ESXi hosts can handle more concurrent migrations without experiencing network congestion or slowdowns.

questions.question_text:
An administrator needs to migrate a powered off virtual machine to another cluster with no shared storage.
Which option should the administrator select for a successful migration?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
B is the correct answer.
If a VM is being migrated to another cluster that does not have shared storage than both compute resource and storage option needs to be checked.
Answer should be B

When migrating a powered-off virtual machine to another cluster with no shared storage, the appropriate option for a successful migration is:

A. Change compute resource only

Selecting the "Change compute resource only" option will allow the administrator to move the powered-off virtual machine to another cluster without any impact on the storage. This migration process will only relocate the VM's compute resources, such as its configuration, settings, and associations with the host and cluster, while keeping its storage intact.

questions.question_text:
A system administrator is preparing a host in a vSphere DRS cluster in partially automated mode for firmware patching and puts a host into maintenance mode.
After several minutes, the host still has not entered maintenance mode.
How should the system administrator resolve this problem?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
B is correct
Virtual machines that are running on a host entering maintenance mode need to be migrated to another host (either manually or automatically by DRS) or shut down. The host is in a state of Entering Maintenance Mode until all running virtual machines are powered down or migrated to different hosts. You cannot power on virtual machines or migrate virtual machines to a host entering maintenance mode. 
https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-vSphere/7.0/com.vmware.vsphere.resmgmt.doc/GUID-8F705E83-6788-42D4-93DF-63A2B892367F.html

choices.D: vSphere HA admission control needs to be enabled on the cluster.
choices.A: The system administrator needs to schedule DRS to run again.
choices.B: The system administrator needs to migrate virtual machines using vSphere vMotion.
choices.C: vSphere Lifecycle Manager and DRS integration need to be configured.

questions.question_text:
A vSphere operator finds this error message:
Device or filesystem with identifier [naa.1234567890] has entered the All Paths Down state.
What should the operator conclude from this error message?

choices.D: A storage device has failed and is not expected to become available.
choices.C: A host is inaccessible, and migration of affected VMs is expected.
choices.B: A storage device is inaccessible and is expected to become available.
choices.A: A host failed, and automated recovery of affected VMs is expected.

discussion.content:
Answer is B.
https://kb.vmware.com/s/article/2032934

Selected Answer: B
The error message "Device or filesystem with identifier [naa.1234567890] has entered the All Paths Down state" indicates that:

B. A storage device is inaccessible and is expected to become available.

This error message typically means that the storage device associated with the specified identifier (in this case, identified by the NAA - Network Address Authority) has lost connectivity or become inaccessible from the perspective of the ESXi host. The "All Paths Down" state suggests that all paths from the host to the storage device are unavailable or disconnected.

In such cases, the expected scenario is that the storage device might be temporarily unavailable or experiencing issues, and there's an anticipation or hope that it will regain connectivity or become available again, allowing access to the storage resources once the issue is resolved.

Selected Answer: B

B
A storage device is inaccessible and is expected to become available.

All-Paths-Down (APD) situation occurs when all paths to a device are down. As there is no indication of whether this is a permanent or temporary device loss, the ESXi host keeps reattempting to establish connectivity. APD-style situations commonly occur when the LUN is incorrectly un-presented from the ESXi host.

Could be C or B

questions.question_text:
A group of VMs is experiencing high latency on a portgroup in an ESXi host.
Which option can a vSphere administrator use to move some of the VMs to another portgroup?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
The question is related to the move of the VM.

Selected Answer: B
The key wording on this question is "moving VMs to another Port Group" to address the network latency. so Vmotion to another host (presumably a fellow cluster member) with a corresponding standard switch and identically named Port Group will meet the requirement. IP hash would definitely address the network latency by taking full advantage of load balancing of multiple NICs configured as an EtherChannel but again , it mentions how to solve the problem by moving VMs to another port group.

Selected Answer: C
In an environment with multiple virtual machines, load is spread across all active NICs for better performance.
